page.lettertext:
fol.178r
S
r
Thomas Bodley to William Lord Burghley
May it please your good L
ordship
The bearer heerof
John Minche
, having served a long time in these countreys
was taken prisoner by the Ennemy about 5 weekes past
and brought p
ntl
y to
Bolduc
& from thence to
Bruxels
&
last of all to
Andwerpe.
In
e time of his imprisonm
t
he had conference in Bruxels w
th
one
John Damport
a
Cheshire gentleman, and a Pensioner of
e
King of Spaine
who seeming to bee weary of
e King
service, and desirous
to forsake
e companie of
e Englishe fugitives discovered
his minde to this bearer, and willed him w
th
out all
delay to repaire into
England,
& there notefie speedily
that there were certain Englishmen in Bruxels w
ch
had a
mischievous practise in hand upon her
Ma
t
shippes. For
the effecting wherof they had sent certaine mariners
into England appareled like Burgers, w
ch
were addressed to
a Duche mans house in
S
t
Katherins
neere to
e
Towre,
who bestoweth them in service in
e foresaid shippes, w
th
instruction to watche an opportunity to sett them on fire.
The truthe heerof I knowe no t otherwise but by his
owne report, who as far as I can
ceave hath no
other proofe nor conjecture but by
e speeches of John
Damport; w
ch
also I knowe not how truly he avoucheth
Nevertheles because hee offereth of him self to make
this voyage, requiring nothing of mee but to give his
meanes by a letter unto yo
r
L, or some other of my
LL
. to have accesse, I thought to write thus much
by him, and to signifie heer unto him, that if by
his travell and service the parties bee descried, hee
wilbee well rewarded, otherwise I could make him
no promise, not hee mighte not build upon it, for
his onely good will, & this bare declaration to receave
any recompense,
and thus &c. Hage June 6
1591.
Your Lordships &C Tho. Bodley
